title: 108_hr5403
content: The Act titled "Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004" aims to improve the quality of long term care in skilled nursing facilities under Medicare. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 requires skilled nursing facilities to provide detailed reporting of nursing expenditures, including wages and benefits for nursing staff by staff level. Additionally, the Act mandates the development and reporting of new quality measures by the Secretary. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 mandates skilled nursing facilities to report nursing expenditures and develop new quality measures in consultation with experts and stakeholders. Quality measures may include process, structural, and outcome measures for use in a payment system. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 requires skilled nursing facilities to report nursing expenditures and develop quality measures, including structural and outcome measures for a payment system. Quality measures must be valid, reliable, and include staffing levels. Special provisions are made for small facilities. The Secretary will post the information online. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 mandates skilled nursing facilities to report nursing expenditures and establish quality measures for a payment system. Special provisions are made for small facilities, and the Secretary will post new quality performance measures online. Payment rates are maintained at a minimum level, with adjustments made for quality performance. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 requires skilled nursing facilities to report nursing expenditures and establish quality measures for a payment system. Payment rates are maintained at a minimum level, with adjustments made for quality performance, linking payment rates to quality indicators. The Secretary will develop and test methods for this purpose in consultation with various stakeholders. The Long Term Care Quality Improvement Act of 2004 mandates skilled nursing facilities to report nursing expenditures and establish quality measures for payment. Payment rates will be tied to quality indicators, with a portion dependent on performance. The Secretary will develop and test new payment methods through pilot studies and other appropriate methods. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the adequacy of public payments and future financing options for quality nursing facility care, including Medicaid financing, Medicare's cross-subsidization, industry margins, trends impact, and demographic changes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will provide annual reports to Congress on the adequacy of public payments and future financing options for quality nursing facility care, including Medicaid financing, Medicare's cross-subsidization, industry margins, trends impact, and demographic changes. Additionally, a final report will be submitted to Congress within 5 years of the enactment of this Act, detailing the results of the study conducted. The Secretary will submit a final report to Congress within 5 years of the Act's enactment, including study results, impact on care quality, payment system recommendations, and analysis of alternative approaches.
